conclusion: To find the magnitude of the pressure exerted by the sled on the ground, we need to consider the forces acting on the sled and the child.
The weight of the child: \( W_{\text{child}} = m_{\text{child}} \cdot g = 30 \, \text{kg} \times 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 300 \, \text{N} \)
The weight of the sled: \( W_{\text{sled}} = m_{\text{sled}} \cdot g = 10 \, \text{kg} \times 10 \, \text{m/s}^2 = 100 \, \text{N} \)
The pulling force: \( F = 100 \, \text{N} \) at an angle of \( 37^\circ \)

The pulling force: \( F = 100 \, \text{N} \) at an angle of \( 37^\circ \)
The weight of the child: \( W_{\text{child}} = 300 \, \text{N} \), The weight of the sled: \( W_{\text{sled}} = 100 \, \text{N} \), Vertical component: \( F_y = 60 \, \text{N} \)
conclusion: The normal force \( N \) is the force exerted by the ground on the sled, which balances the vertical forces. The total downward force is the sum of the weights minus the vertical component of the pulling force: \( N = W_{\text{child}} + W_{\text{sled}} - F_y = 300 \, \text{N} + 100 \, \text{N} - 60 \, \text{N} = 340 \, \text{N} \)
The pressure exerted by the sled on the ground is equal to the normal force, as the sled is in equilibrium and moving at a constant speed.
